section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Retold by Jim Aylesworth Illustrated by Barbara McClintock
section-block.rac_book_summary: A boy loses the mitten knitted by his grandmother while playing in the snow. But a squirrel finds it! And then a rabbit! And even more animals! This classic tale has many opportunities to count and add as animals crawl into the mitten for warmth.

section-block.rac_body-text: Guide children to count to ten and back to one, each child saying one number. Explain that each time you count up, you add one. When you count down, you take one away.
(Tune: “Row, Row, Row Your Boat”)Add, add, add one moreEvery time you count.Where you’ve begun, count up oneThat’s the right amount!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Mitten by Jim Aylesworth.
Lala loves all sorts of books. She loves looking for ways to add and take away in stories like this one.
What is one animal that goes into the mitten?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Operations: Practice adding one more as each new animal enters the mitten.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The boy is wearing mittens. They were made for him by his grandmother. We’re going to read about what happens to one of these mittens.
Let’s look closely at the picture. Point to each mitten in the pictures.
The boy lost a mitten! He had two, but lost one. Let’s count back one from two: Two, one. The boy has one mitten now.
We’re going to keep track of how many animals go into the mitten. The squirrel is one.
What does the rabbit want? (MB)
There was one animal in the mitten before. Let’s add one more for the rabbit: one, two. How many animals are in the mitten?
Now a bear wants to go in the mitten! Let’s count one more than three to say how many animals are in the mitten now: three, four.
Here comes a mouse! Let’s count one more than four: four, five.
What happened to the mitten?
There were too many animals when the mouse joined! Let’s count back one from five. How many animals fit in the mitten before the mouse joined?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question: What is one animal that goes into the mitten?
section.rac_body-text: Guide children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: A squirrel goes into the mitten.
A rabbit goes into the mitten.
A bear goes into the mitten.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about cold weather as children watch.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: A b____ (bear) goes into the mitten.
A bear goes into the mitten.
Where do you go when it is cold outside?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Adding And Removing One
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Encourage children to think of the next number in a counting sequence as “one more,” and the previous number as “one less.” By implementing rational counting rather than rote counting, children begin to see that counting up is the same as adding one more, and counting down is the same as removing one – an important operations skill.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Talk About Your Needs

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Everyone has needs. A need is something that is very important to life, like having food to eat and water to drink. A need can also be your need to go to the bathroom! It’s important to know what you need, and to be able to tell others in a way that is polite and kind. Often, other people are the ones who can help make sure your needs are taken care of.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will revisit some pages of The Mitten by Jim Aylesworth. We will think about what the characters need and how they communicate those needs.
Clifford loves to read stories where characters share what they need. It helps him learn how he can share his needs with others.

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Operations: Guide children to use their fingers for support to add and take away animals.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How did the grandmother know the boy needed a hug and a hot drink? What did he do to communicate his needs? (MB)
What does the squirrel communicate to the rabbit? What need does the squirrel have?
Have you ever needed to be alone, or to have more space? How could you politely ask for more space? (MB)
What need does the fox have? How does the fox communicate that need? (MB)
Let’s count the animals in the mitten before. Now, let’s count up one from two because the fox is getting in the mitten. How many animals are in the mitten now?
How does the mouse communicate its needs? Is the mouse polite? What about the animals who need their space? How many animals are in the mitten now? (MB)
How many animals are left when the mouse leaves? We can say how many animals by counting down one from five.

section.rac_body-text: Ask children to think of their needs during cold weather. Provide paper and drawing materials, and encourage children to depict themselves in cold weather. Do they need a heavy coat? Snowboots? Tailor the discussion and children’s illustrations to the climate in your area.
Transcribe children’s speech as they tell about one of their needs.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Help children realize that they can communicate their needs both verbally and nonverbally, and that asking politely is usually received better than demanding something. Children may not be able to identify complex needs at first. Talk about basic human needs, namely food, shelter, and clothing, and encourage them to speak up about their personal needs. (Read, 1980)

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children who their favorite animal is in The Mitten. Have children stand in lines for each animal. We’ve made a bar graph! Which character is most liked?
Sort children into groups: Everyone wearing blue on this side! Everyone not to that side! Compare totals in each group. Repeat using different properties to sort.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread The MItten by Jim Aylesworth.
Lala loves reading books that tell a story.
Think about this question while we read: Why do the animals go in the mitten?

section.rac_body-text: Pause to have children place sticky notes on a board or chart to create a bar graph that sorts the animals into big and small.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s look closely at the pictures of the boy in spring. What does the weather look like? Does he need a coat? What does the weather look like in summer? Autumn? Winter?
Why does grandma knit the little boy a hat, scarf, and mittens?
The squirrel fits in the mitten! Is the squirrel big or small? Who can put a sticky note above small?
Why does the rabbit go into the mitten? Where should we place the sticky note: big or small?
How many animals are in the mitten? Let’s count!
How many animals are outside of the mitten? Let’s count!
What is the total number of animals on this page?
section.rac_body-text: Guide children to discuss whether the fox is big or small and place the sticky note in the corresponding column.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Is the bear small or big?
What does the bear need? How does the bear tell the other animals? (MB)
Is the mouse small or big? Who can put a sticky note on the graph?
What does each bar tell us? Are there more small animals or big animals? How can you tell?
Why do the animals go in the mitten?
section.rac_body-text: Ask children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to choose several children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: It was warm inside the mitten.
The animals wanted to feel warm.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about what they like to do to keep warm.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How did the animals want to feel?
The animals wanted to feel w____ (warm).
The animals wanted to feel warm.
What do you do when you want to be warm?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children with a different home language or culture, especially those from warmer climates, might not be familiar with the word mitten. Share a mitten and let children examine it. Discuss other cold weather terms and concepts like snow, ice/icy, winter, and scarf.

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk about the weather at the beginning of The Mitten. We saw the boy playing in sunny weather and in snowy weather. What other kinds of weather do you know?
Tell each child a type of weather, and ask them to act out an activity they would do in that weather without using any words. Have other children guess the activity.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read What’s the Weather? It is an informational poster full of facts.
Lala loves to learn about the weather. She wonders what the weather is outside right now!
What’s the Weather? and The Mitten both focus on different kinds of weather. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read!
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to the concept question:
How can weather affect us?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask these questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is the weather like today? Let’s look out the window! How is the sky different from or similar to these pictures?
What do you think clouds fill up with before it rains? What does the sky look like before it rains? How do rainclouds look different from other clouds?
Why is it important to wear a warm jacket in snowy weather? What do you need when it is cold outside? (MB)
Have you ever flown a kite? What does the sky look like on a windy day?
How can you tell that it is sunny in this picture? Sometimes when it is sunny, it is also hot. What is something you might need when it’s hot outside? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Have children draw their favorite type of weather: sunny, windy, snowy, or rainy. Once children have finished their drawings, ask them to describe why that type of weather is their favorite. Then, work together to sort the pictures into a class bar graph, separated by weather type.
Provide a writing prompt about how weather affects what you wear. Give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: There are plenty of activities children can enjoy doing during just about any kind of weather. Help children think of healthy activities they can do when it is rainy, snowy, sunny, cold, hot, or windy outside. Get them excited about being able to play for a whole hour every day no matter what the weather is!

section-block.rac_body-text: Noticing changes in weather is an important science skill. Ask children to describe the weather each day, and encourage them to include how the sky looks in their description.
Ask two children to pretend they are sound asleep. Then, ask one more child to “sleep.” Ask the class to tell you the new total of “sleeping” children. Repeat.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read The Mitten one more time this week.
Lala wonders if this book tells a story or gives information. Which is it?
We have learned about many ways the weather can affect what we do and what we wear. When we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How does the cold weather affect the boy and the animals?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book one more time. This time we’ll act out parts of the story.
What kind of weather is the boy playing in?
Let’s count all of the snowballs in this picture. How many will there be when the boy throws one? Let’s count back one from seven.
Who can pretend to throw a snowball?
The squirrel thinks the mitten looks cozy. Let’s pretend to curl up in a big, cozy mitten.
The squirrel fell sound asleep. Pretend to be sound asleep.
Is sleep a need that you have too? How can you let someone know when you are tired? (MB)
The fox is cold! How does the fox show that he is cold? (MB)
Let’s pretend to shiver like the fox!
Oh no! What happened to the mitten? Who can show us what it looks like to spill out from the mitten into the snow?

It looks like grandma has six balls of yarn in her basket. The boy and the cat are playing with a ball of yarn too! How many balls of yarn are there in all? Let’s count up one from six to get the total.
How does the cold weather affect the boy and the animals?
section.rac_body-text: Guide children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: The boy needs to wear a wool hat and gloves.
The animals need to sleep in the mitten because it’s cold.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write a story about what they like to do when it is cold.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why does the boy wear mittens?
The boy wears mittens because it is so c____ (cold).
The boy wears mittens because it is so cold.
What is your favorite thing to do when it is cold outside?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children may lose track when counting non-tangible items instead of counting actual objects. Guide children to use their fingers or other manipulatives to help them count the “sleeping” children, holding up two fingers on one hand and one in the other to represent 2 + 1 more concretely.
